statement.text: Conventional catheter-based angiography (digital subtraction angiography, DSA) remains the gold standard for mesenteric vascular imaging with unparalleled spatial and temporal resolution, though its invasive nature has relegated it primarily to cases requiring immediate endovascular intervention or when non-invasive imaging is inconclusive.
statement.formal: DSA Indications: (1) When CTA inconclusive, (2) When endovascular treatment planned, (3) For pressure measurements or provocative testing; Advantages: Real-time flow assessment, immediate intervention capability; Disadvantages: Invasive, contrast nephrotoxicity, access complications

explanation.intuition: While CTA has largely replaced diagnostic angiography for mesenteric ischemia, catheter angiography offers unique advantages: real-time visualization of flow dynamics, the ability to selectively catheterize vessels, and immediate transition to therapy. In the hybrid OR era, angiography is often the first step of an intervention rather than a standalone diagnostic test.
explanation.key_insight: The modern role of conventional angiography is primarily therapeutic rather than purely diagnostic. When mesenteric ischemia is strongly suspected and intervention is planned, proceeding directly to the angiography suite allows diagnosis and treatment in a single session.
explanation.technical_details: Selective mesenteric angiography requires catheterization of the celiac, SMA, and IMA origins. DSA technique with rapid frame acquisition is essential for optimal visualization. CO2 angiography is an alternative for patients with severe renal impairment.

considerations.femoral: Large sheath accommodates intervention catheters; familiar anatomy
considerations.radial: Lower access site complications; may limit device size
considerations.brachial: Higher neurologic complication risk; used if femoral unsuitable

catheter_selection.for_ima: Often straightforward from aorta; catheter with inferior angulation
catheter_selection.microcatheters: For selective branch cannulation, distal intervention

aortography.purpose: Overview of all three mesenteric origins
aortography.views: Lateral (best for ostial lesions) and AP

selective_catheterization.technique: Hand injection or power injector with reduced rate

iodinated.dose: Minimize total volume; typically 100-150 mL for diagnostic

co2_angiography.technique: CO2 as negative contrast; requires special injector
co2_angiography.limitations: Lower image quality, cannot use above diaphragm (air embolism risk)

gadolinium.consideration: Nephrogenic systemic fibrosis risk if GFR <30

embolism.location: Usually 3-10 cm from SMA origin (just past middle colic takeoff)

nomi.note: Diagnosis often made by exclusion of occlusive disease

pharmacological_thrombolysis.indication: Acute thrombosis, small-vessel embolism, selected acute-on-chronic
pharmacological_thrombolysis.duration: Hours to overnight infusion with repeat angiography
pharmacological_thrombolysis.limitation: Largely supplanted by mechanical thrombectomy for acute AMI

mechanical_thrombectomy.advantage: Rapid recanalization, less bleeding risk than lysis
mechanical_thrombectomy.current_trend: First-line for acute AMI in many centers

vasodilator_infusion.technique: Catheter positioned in SMA, continuous infusion

current_practice.dsa: When CTA inconclusive or intervention planned
current_practice.hybrid_approach: CTA for diagnosis, proceed to angio suite if intervention needed

contrast_related: Contrast-induced nephropathy (2-10% depending on baseline GFR)

clinical_pearls.pearl: Lateral aortography is essential for assessing mesenteric ostial disease—AP views can underestimate stenosis severity
clinical_pearls.implication: Always include lateral projection when evaluating for CMI

clinical_pearls.pearl: In acute AMI, the location of the embolus (distal to proximal SMA branches) helps distinguish embolism from thrombosis and guides therapy
clinical_pearls.implication: Embolus spares proximal branches; thrombosis involves the origin

clinical_pearls.pearl: Angiography should be performed with the capability and intent to intervene—don't just diagnose, be prepared to treat
clinical_pearls.implication: Have intervention equipment available when doing mesenteric angiography for AMI

clinical_pearls.pearl: CO2 angiography can be a life-saving alternative in patients with severe renal dysfunction or contrast allergy
clinical_pearls.implication: Familiarize yourself with CO2 technique for these situations
